event.subject: PostGIS defaults to gen OID
event.body: from http://postgis.refractions.net/pipermail/postgis-users/2005-November/010075.html. New version of Postgresql (8.1) does not create OID column by default when creating a table (oid is globally unique identifiers used by Postgresql and also used by Mapserver to uniquely identify a row of result). My solution was to enable oid-generation in postgresql, by editing the postgresql.conf (in the postgresql/8.1/data folder) Search for "default_with_oids", uncomment the line and set the variable value to "on". Then, regenerate your postgis tables.

event.subject: PostGIS behind MapServer: motivations
event.body:
From the mailing list topic MapServer with PostGIS: motivations on 2006-08-28.
The more you want to subset or interact with your data, the more you'll benefit from PostGIS. If you have static data and simple map layers, shapefiles are likely to be faster.
Another advantage I have found, is that the PostGIS "simplify" function
provides a very simple & effective way to produce zoom (scale dependent) layers
of vector data. One specific example of the value of having your data in a
manageable structure, rather than simple files

comment.body: Hi, Bruno! I didn't understand when you said that we should be careful if we override some public / protected methods because they might be used internally by other methods. If we decide to design private methods that will be used by another methods in the ancestral class, the subclass won't inherit these methods and the internal implementation of the ancentral class is hiden. Do u agree with this, or not? Could you email me with your opinion? Tks, Rafael Naufal.
I do agree Rafael, you have no problems with private members in your ancestral class, because you just can?t override or use then, so there is no coupling.

event.subject: PostGIS + JDBC
event.body:
1:package net.bpfurtado.postgistest;
   2:
   3:import java.sql.Connection;
   4:import java.sql.DriverManager;
   5:import java.sql.ResultSet;
   6:import java.sql.Statement;
   7:
   8:import org.postgis.PGgeometry;
   9:import org.postgresql.PGConnection;
  10:
  11:public class Main
  12:{
  13:    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception
  14:    {
  15:        Class.forName("org.postgresql.Driver");
  16:        String url = "jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/postgis";
  17:
  18:        Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(url, "postgres", "postgres");
  19:
  20:        PGConnection pgConn = ((org.postgresql.PGConnection) conn);
  21:
  22:        Statement stmt = null;
  23:        try {
  24:            /*
  25:             * Add the geometry types to the connection. 
  26:             * Note that you must cast the connection to the pgsql-specific connection 
  27:             * implementation before calling the addDataType() method.
  28:             * 
  29:             * SELECT AddGeometryColumn('smabc', 'missao', 'posicao_estacao_terrestre', 4326, 'POINT', 2);
  30:             * INSERT INTO smabc.missao (id, posicao_estacao_terrestre) VALUES (1, setsrid(makepoint(324152.222, 7384541.141), 4326));
  31:             */
  32:            pgConn.addDataType("geometry", PGgeometry.class);
  33:
  34:            stmt = conn.createStatement();
  35:            ResultSet rs = stmt.executeQuery("select id, posicao_estacao_terrestre, AsText(posicao_estacao_terrestre) FROM smabc.missao");
  36:            while (rs.next()) {
  37:                int id = rs.getInt(1);
  38:                System.out.println("Row " + id + ":");
  39:
  40:                PGgeometry geom = (PGgeometry) rs.getObject(2);
  41:                System.out.println(geom.toString() + " : " + rs.getObject(3));
  42:            }
  43:        } finally {
  44:            if (stmt != null) {
  45:                stmt.close();
  46:            }
  47:            conn.close();
  48:        }
  49:    }
  50:}

You should use the createlang command. The PostgreSQL Programmer's Guide has the details if you want to this manually for some reason. createlang plpgsql postgis -U postgres psql -d postgis -f ddl.sql -U postgres drop schema mySchema cascade; create schema mySchema; drop table mySchema.monster; CREATE TABLE mySchema.monster ( id integer, nome varchar(128), PRIMARY KEY (id) ); select AddGeometryColumn('mySchema', 'monster', 'atackRadio', '-1', 'MULTIPOLYGON', 2);

event.subject: Postgres comparing strings data types
event.body:
http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.0/static/datatype-character.html
Trailing spaces are disregarded when comparing two values of type character, and they will be removed when converting a character value to one of the other string types. Note that trailing spaces are semantically significant in character varying and text values.
Tip: There are no performance differences between these three types, apart from the increased storage size when using the blank-padded type. While character(n) has performance advantages in some other database systems, it has no such advantages in PostgreSQL. In most situations text or character varying should be used instead.
